articles.headline: Merger-Hungry Italian Banker Wants Europe to Take Fences Down
articles.snippet: Alessandro Profumo wants to build a financial empire that can run with the giants of the United States and, someday, those who may dominate in China.
articles.abstract: Alessandro Profumo wants to build a financial empire that can run with the giants of the United States and, someday, those who may dominate in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILAN, May 11  Few business executives are as determined to forge a single European market as Alessandro Profumo, the ambitious Italian banker who last year took over Germany's second-largest bank, HVB. Yet as he reflects on the cross-border foray of his bank, UniCredit Group, Mr. Profumo admits to being tripped up by age-old cultural differences.

articles.headline: Army Acts to Curb Abuses of Injured Recruits
articles.snippet: Soldiers and their parents said troops injured at Fort Sill were punished with abuse and neglect.
articles.abstract: Soldiers and their parents said troops injured at Fort Sill were punished with abuse and neglect.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWTON, Okla. — The Army has shaken up a program to heal recruits injured in basic training after soldiers and their parents said troops hurt at Fort Sill were punished with physical abuse and medical neglect.

articles.headline: Higher Learning in France Clings to Its Old Ways
articles.snippet: France's archaic state-owned university system is overcrowded, underfinanced and disorganized.
articles.abstract: France's archaic state-owned university system is overcrowded, underfinanced and disorganized.
articles.lead_paragraph: NANTERRE, France — There are 32,000 students at the Nanterre campus of the University of Paris, but no student center, no bookstore, no student-run newspaper, no freshman orientation, no corporate recruiting system.

articles.headline: The Higher Cost of Breathing
articles.snippet: A federally mandated shift to a more ozone-friendly version of inhalers used to quell asthma attacks is creating spot shortages of the devices and higher prices.
articles.abstract: A federally mandated shift to a more ozone-friendly version of inhalers used to quell asthma attacks is creating spot shortages of the devices and higher prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: An environmental effort to protect the earth's ozone layer could mean disruptions for the nation's millions of asthma patients.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Tries to Enlist Image Help
articles.snippet: A campaign to encourage suppliers to join Wal-Mart's advocacy group challenges the company's longstanding policy of keeping suppliers at arm's length.
articles.abstract: A campaign to encourage suppliers to join Wal-Mart's advocacy group challenges the company's longstanding policy of keeping suppliers at arm's length.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart, having helped start an advocacy group that trumpets its contributions to America, is now helping that organization recruit Wal-Mart's suppliers to join the public relations offensive — a move that some vendors say puts improper pressure on them.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Eyes Organic Foods
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart wants to sell more organic food — and because of its size and clout, Wal-Mart usually gets what it wants.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart wants to sell more organic food — and because of its size and clout, Wal-Mart usually gets what it wants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starting this summer, there will be a lot more organic food on supermarket shelves, and it should cost a lot less.

articles.headline: Inflation Stirs Worry on Wall St.
articles.snippet: Stock prices fell sharply and broadly yesterday as investors worried that rising oil prices would quicken the pace of inflation and force policy makers to raise interest rates further.     The abrupt drop, which was the largest since January, came...
articles.abstract: Stock prices fell sharply and broadly yesterday as investors worried that rising oil prices would quicken the pace of inflation and force policy makers to raise interest rates further.     The abrupt drop, which was the largest since January, came after several days of modest but steady increases in the Dow Jones industrial average, which as recently as Wednesday was within 80 points of its record high. It also came a day after the Federal Reserve indicated that it was ambiguous about whether it would raise rates later this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock prices fell sharply and broadly yesterday as investors worried that rising oil prices would quicken the pace of inflation and force policy makers to raise interest rates further.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: The Higher Cost of Breathing
articles.snippet: An environmental effort to protect the earth's ozone layer could mean disruptions for the nation's millions of asthma patients.      A federally mandated shift to a more ozone-friendly version of the hand-held inhalers used to quell asthma attacks...
articles.abstract: An environmental effort to protect the earth's ozone layer could mean disruptions for the nation's millions of asthma patients.      A federally mandated shift to a more ozone-friendly version of the hand-held inhalers used to quell asthma attacks is creating spot shortages of the devices, because production of the older versions has declined even before producers of the new inhalers ramp up fully. The shift is also giving a few drug makers the rare chance to introduce brand-name medicine into a market long dominated by low-cost generics.
articles.lead_paragraph: An environmental effort to protect the earth's ozone layer could mean disruptions for the nation's millions of asthma patients.

articles.headline: Bush Is Pressed Over New Report on Surveillance
articles.snippet: Congressional Republicans and Democrats alike demanded answers from the Bush administration on Thursday about a report that the National Security Agency had collected records of millions of domestic phone calls, even as President Bush assured Amer...
articles.abstract: Congressional Republicans and Democrats alike demanded answers from the Bush administration on Thursday about a report that the National Security Agency had collected records of millions of domestic phone calls, even as President Bush assured Americans that their privacy is ''fiercely protected.''      ''We're not mining or trolling through the personal lives of millions of innocent Americans,'' Mr. Bush said before leaving for a commencement address in Mississippi. ''Our efforts are focused on links to Al Qaeda and their known affiliates.''
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 11 - Congressional Republicans and Democrats alike demanded answers from the Bush administration on Thursday about a report that the National Security Agency had collected records of millions of domestic phone calls, even as President Bush assured Americans that their privacy is "fiercely protected."
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Senate Approves Extension of Bush Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: The Senate voted 54 to 44 on Thursday to pass almost $70 billion in tax cuts, mostly for the nation's wealthiest taxpayers. The action ensures that virtually all of President Bush's tax cuts will be locked in place until after the next presidentia...
articles.abstract: The Senate voted 54 to 44 on Thursday to pass almost $70 billion in tax cuts, mostly for the nation's wealthiest taxpayers. The action ensures that virtually all of President Bush's tax cuts will be locked in place until after the next presidential election.     The measure, which the House passed Wednesday, would extend Mr. Bush's tax cuts on stock dividends and capital gains by two years, until 2010, and shield about 15 million taxpayers for one year from an increase in the alternative minimum tax.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 11 - The Senate voted 54 to 44 on Thursday to pass almost $70 billion in tax cuts, mostly for the nation's wealthiest taxpayers. The action ensures that virtually all of President Bush's tax cuts will be locked in place until after the next presidential election.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Eyes Organic Foods
articles.snippet: Starting this summer, there will be a lot more organic food on supermarket shelves, and it should cost a lot less.     Most of the nation's major food producers are hard at work developing organic versions of their best-selling products, like Kell...
articles.abstract: Starting this summer, there will be a lot more organic food on supermarket shelves, and it should cost a lot less.     Most of the nation's major food producers are hard at work developing organic versions of their best-selling products, like Kellogg's Rice Krispies and Kraft's macaroni and cheese.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starting this summer, there will be a lot more organic food on supermarket shelves, and it should cost a lot less.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Tries to Enlist Image Help
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart, having helped start an advocacy group that trumpets its contributions to America, is now helping that organization recruit Wal-Mart's suppliers to join the public relations offensive -- a move that some vendors say puts improper pressure...
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart, having helped start an advocacy group that trumpets its contributions to America, is now helping that organization recruit Wal-Mart's suppliers to join the public relations offensive -- a move that some vendors say puts improper pressure on them.     The campaign to encourage suppliers to join the advocacy group, called Working Families for Wal-Mart, challenges Wal-Mart's longstanding policy of keeping suppliers at arm's length and shows how eager the company is to fend off a well-organized union-backed campaign critical of its wages and benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart, having helped start an advocacy group that trumpets its contributions to America, is now helping that organization recruit Wal-Mart's suppliers to join the public relations offensive -- a move that some vendors say puts improper pressure on them.

articles.headline: Arrest of Grand Juror Is Latest Twist in Insider Trading Case
articles.snippet: It started with suspicious trades by a retired seamstress in Croatia and grew to include a cast of low-level Wall Street professionals and an exotic dancer. Now, one of the largest insider trading scandals in decades has taken another unlikely tur...
articles.abstract: It started with suspicious trades by a retired seamstress in Croatia and grew to include a cast of low-level Wall Street professionals and an exotic dancer. Now, one of the largest insider trading scandals in decades has taken another unlikely turn -- into the grand jury room.     A postal worker, Jason C. Smith of Jersey City, was arrested yesterday and charged with leaking secret information from grand jury proceedings to David Pajcin and Eugene Plotkin, the two men previously accused of running an insider trading ring that reaped $6.7 million in illegal profits in 2004 and 2005.
articles.lead_paragraph: It started with suspicious trades by a retired seamstress in Croatia and grew to include a cast of low-level Wall Street professionals and an exotic dancer. Now, one of the largest insider trading scandals in decades has taken another unlikely turn -- into the grand jury room.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Shift in Treating Breast Cancer Is Under Debate
articles.snippet: Doctors who treat women with breast cancer are glimpsing the possibility of a vastly different future. After years of adding more and more to the regimen -- more drugs, shorter intervals between chemotherapy sessions, higher doses, longer periods ...
articles.abstract: Doctors who treat women with breast cancer are glimpsing the possibility of a vastly different future. After years of adding more and more to the regimen -- more drugs, shorter intervals between chemotherapy sessions, higher doses, longer periods of a harsh therapy -- they are now wondering whether many women could skip chemotherapy altogether.      If the new ideas, supported by a recent report, are validated by large studies like two that are just beginning, the treatment of breast cancer will markedly change.
articles.lead_paragraph: Doctors who treat women with breast cancer are glimpsing the possibility of a vastly different future. After years of adding more and more to the regimen -- more drugs, shorter intervals between chemotherapy sessions, higher doses, longer periods of a harsh therapy -- they are now wondering whether many women could skip chemotherapy altogether.

articles.headline: Merger-Hungry Italian Banker Wants Europe to Take Fences Down
articles.snippet: Few business executives are as determined to forge a single European market as Alessandro Profumo, the ambitious Italian banker who last year took over Germany's second-largest bank, HVB. Yet as he reflects on the cross-border foray of his bank, U...
articles.abstract: Few business executives are as determined to forge a single European market as Alessandro Profumo, the ambitious Italian banker who last year took over Germany's second-largest bank, HVB. Yet as he reflects on the cross-border foray of his bank, UniCredit Group, Mr. Profumo admits to being tripped up by age-old cultural differences.     ''Italians are warm and more emotional; Germans are more rational,'' he said in an interview at UniCredit's headquarters here.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILAN, May 11 - Few business executives are as determined to forge a single European market as Alessandro Profumo, the ambitious Italian banker who last year took over Germany's second-largest bank, HVB. Yet as he reflects on the cross-border foray of his bank, UniCredit Group, Mr. Profumo admits to being tripped up by age-old cultural differences.

articles.headline: Army Acts to Curb Abuses of Injured Recruits
articles.snippet: The Army has shaken up a program to heal recruits injured in basic training after soldiers and their parents said troops hurt at Fort Sill were punished with physical abuse and medical neglect.      The program, which treated more than 1,100 injur...
articles.abstract: The Army has shaken up a program to heal recruits injured in basic training after soldiers and their parents said troops hurt at Fort Sill were punished with physical abuse and medical neglect.      The program, which treated more than 1,100 injured soldiers last year at five posts, normally returns three-fourths of its patients to active duty, according to Army statistics. But at Fort Sill, recruits said, injuries were often subject to derision, ignored or improperly treated.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWTON, Okla. - The Army has shaken up a program to heal recruits injured in basic training after soldiers and their parents said troops hurt at Fort Sill were punished with physical abuse and medical neglect.
